text:
Thankyou for posting this as it really resonates with my mindset over last few months (especially the stuff about isolation and mental/physical health). Despite having another good year profit wise, I've been getting a downer on the game and also considering getting a "real" job now as me and my partner are trying to get a mortgage. I'm fortunate as 1) I have a good lump earned from this game to pay a deposit and 2) she earns a pretty good wage but it has really hammered home the notion that I am basically "off-grid" when it comes to a lot of things now.
It is strange, you work hard make profit, have the luxury of deciding to quit working for other people but it does come at a price.

text: Seems a bit self-indulgent to complain about it and its a very first-world problem. We as automated players have the best of it too - I would not last a month being a manual trader/gambler/poker player stuck at a desk/table for hours on end.

text:
<@UUE6E1LA1> why not have a real job AND do this? 
i enjoy having a job too and get to travel and meet people which I enjoy
i guess it all depends on what your job is and whether you like it or not ?

text: <@UQL0QDEKA> I did try this. I was out of work at the peak of pandemic as my contract was not renewed so turned to this full time. Was approached by a betting company and started working there - great chaps but I honestly could not get motivated. I was getting paid a quarter of what I was making in profits on Betfair and the London commute was costing me 3 hours a day (had to be on site 3 days a week). That combined with not enjoying what they had me working on meant my motivation just dropped off a cliff and I ended up resigning. I think that I would have the same problem anywhere else now so if I did end up on the grid again I think I would have to just be self-employed in some way. Didn't help that it was a startup and most of the people were really enthusiastic youngsters at that live-to-work stage of their lives. They were all great people but I am at that age now where going on the piss after work is not what I am looking for so I missed out on a lot of the social stuff I would have lapped up 20 years ago. The penny finally dropped when they had some golf up on one of the internal TVs and some young shaver referred to Sergio Garcia as "one of the old guard"

text: :smile: that final paragraph made me laugh. I work from home and can usually do my day job in an hour two tops. I hate travelling in London so yes I understand you better now. Good luck anyway DC, time is more important to me these days than money if I’m honest

elements.text: that final paragraph made me laugh. I work from home and can usually do my day job in an hour two tops. I hate travelling in London so yes I understand you better now. Good luck anyway DC, time is more important to me these days than money if

text:
Over the years nearly everyone has questioned my day job when I have betfair. I think the post sums it up well but looking back now it has certainly accelerated my wealth from being able to lean on what the average joe considers normal (for example mortgages)

There is more to it as well, I only contract about a day a week now but get invited to socials, leaving drinks, Christmas parties etc, all excuses to leave the screen and pretend to be normal once a month. Regarding the work I am currently exploring on integrating an LLM on a result set in real time, interesting / real world problems that get visibility from others which makes it more rewarding. Coming up to over 2 years at my current role I am probably due a change..

text: I can see the appeal of a contract where you only do one day a week. I'll be honest though I've never heard of any contract positions that want such a short amount of time per week. Is this a consultancy type gig <@U4H19D1D2> ?

text: Yeah I think that is the hard part, in my case made possible by being at the company for so long, started nearly 10 years ago now. Built a few apps, automated everything I could allowing me to step back and let others run, just work on new features / domains etc.
